PRICE, FIVE CENTS

BRINGS BIG COLLECTION OF ORES

SOPHOMORES AND FRESHMEN TIE

DR. WOOD MAKES DISCOVERIES

HOPKINS MEN AT MEETING

Dr. Singewald, on Return from South
America, Reports Gathering of Valuable Mineral Specimens—Ore
Deposits Studied.

Underclass Teams Fight at Homewood
to Standstill - -Sophs Have Advantage, but Fail to Score at
Critical Times.

Planets Found by Him to Show Different
New Features When Photographed
by Varied Processes at Mount
Wilson, California.

Many University Representatives Present
at National Defense Gathering at
Lyric—Much Spirit Shown—T.R.
Sends Congratulations.

Dr. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr.,
associate in economic geology at
Johns Hopkins University, has just
returned from a seven months' tour
of South and Central America,
bringing with him the most valuable collection of South American
ores that has ever been brought
together at one time. He was accompanied on the trip by Prof.
Benjamin L. Miller, of Lehigh
University, a graduate in geology
of this University.
The purpose of the trip was to
make a study of the ore deposits
of Latin America. In the course
of the trip, Professor Singewald
visited practically all of the most
important mines of the countries
through which he passed.
In addition to the value of this
material for museum and lecture
Purposes, much of it is of scientific
importance, It includes fossils
from two series of rocks in Bolivia
in which fossils had never before
been found, whose study is expected to throw great light upon the
geological history of the Andes.
Data was also collected from the
nitrate fields of Chile which will
Probably help to settle the vexatious problem of their origin. Results bearing on the problems of
ore genesis are expected from the
laboratory investigations of the ore
specimens.
South America has the most
varied mineral deposits of all the
continents, and many mineralogical
specimens of particular value were
obtained. Among the most striking additions to the mineral collections of the University are large
specimens of native bismuth from
Huayna Potosi, near La Paz, Bolivia, a mineral that is only found
in small quantities elsewhere; a
magnificent specimen of silver ore
from near Cerro de Pasco, Peru;
arborescent bunches of native copner from Coroco, Bolivia; and
great quantities of the otherwise
rare oxidized basic copper ores that
occur so abundantly in the Atacama
desert in Chile.
Dr. Singewald was much impressed with the •important position
that South America deserves and is
rapidly establishing for herself as a
contributor to the world's supply
of metals. Her progress in this
spect is shown by the number of
Points in which she holds first place.
Dr. Singewald also came into contact in every region which he visited with the activities of foreign
nations in the development of the
country.

The annual freshman-sophomore
football game, played Saturday at
Homewood, ended in a scoreless tie.
It was a hard-fought battle throughout, with the sophomores perhaps
having a little the better of the argument. The play was in freshman
territory practically the whole game,
the second-year men twice getting
within striking distance of the freshmen's goal. But the sophomores
lacked the punch at the critical moments, and the first-year men were
able to keep their goal line untouched.
Hoffman had two chances to
drop-kick, but both attempts went
far from their mark. At the end
of the first half the sophomores
were close to the goal line, but instead of attempting a drop-kick the
second-year men tried for a touchdown and were held for downs by
the freshies on their i-yard line.
The contest started off with a
rush. Hoffman kicked off. The
sophs were very fast getting down
the field and a general scramble for
the ball ensued. A first-year man
finally fell on it. They failed to
gain, and on the fourth down Frock
kick ed to Hoffman. Duncan
plunged through center and made it
first down. In three successive
rushes Hoffman netted twenty-two
yards, but after each gain his team
was penalized, and he was forced
to kick.
Here ensued a kicking duel between Frock and Hoffman, the
quarter ending with the ball in the
freshmen's possession.
At the beginning of the second
quarter, the freshmen were forced
to kick. Cort missed the ball and
a freshman fell on it. The freshmen then tried a trick play, which
only netted them five yards. The
ball went over on downs.
Hoffman and Duncan now alternated in carrying the ball, and were
able to advance within a yard of
the goal line, but here the freshies
took a brace and held them on the
fourth down. Frock kicked out of
danger. The sophs tried a forward
pass, but missed out by a small
margin.
The half ended with the ball almost in the center of the field.
The third quarter consisted mainly of a kicking duel between Hoffman and Frock, with the advantage
slightly in the soph's favor.
The fourth quarter almost saw
a sophomore victory. Repeated
gains by Duncan and Hoffman
brought the ball under the freshies'

Dr. Robert Wood, Johns Hopkins' celebrated professor of experimental physics, has just retttrned to the University after
making a successful series of experiments at the Mt. Wilson Observatory, situated at Pasadena,
Cal. Dr. Wood's visit to California
was primarily for the purpose of
photographing the moon through
the powerful 60-inch telescope on
Mt. Wilson. However, so much
more material for study was found
among the planets that Dr. Wood
changed his intentions and spent
most of his time photographing
them instead of the 1110011.
In his work, Dr. Wood photographed the moon, Mars, Jupiter
and Saturn with the aid of yellow
light and the ultra-violet and infrared rays. It was found that substances that could be photographed
by means of ultra-violet rays were
at times not shown on the plates
taken with the infra-red rays. For
example, on the ultra-violet photographs Saturn showed a broad,
dark belt around the equator that
could not be seen on the proofs of
the infra-red photographs. Differences in the polar caps and the
rings of Saturn were also noticed.
Dr. Wood explained these phenomena by saying that the atmosphere of the planet possibly contained finely-divided dust or some
gas that was opaque to one kind of
ray and transparent to another.
Jupiter, as well as Saturn,
showed such differences. In order
to discover the nature, of the materials that photograph so differently
under the various rays, it will be
necessary, Dr. Wood says, to make
further investigations. This is now
being done at the California observatory.
In photographing with the infrared and the ultra-violet rays,
screens have to be arranged that
exclude all except the particular
kind of ray to, be used. In the
use of the ultra-violet rays the
light is filtered by means of a glass
cell, closed by quartz and containing bromine vapor.
Dr. Wood is particularly pleased
with the results of these experiments. It is unknown yet just
what importance these facts will
have on our ideas of the planets;
but, at any rate, Dr. Wood's observations are the first of their kind,
and to Dr. Wood belongs the credit
of the discoveries.

Hopkins men were very much in
evidence at the mass-meeting for
national defense, held at the Lyric
Saturday night. The ushers and
many of the vice-presidents were
representatives of the University,
and there were many Hopkins men
in the audience. Governor Goldsborough presided over the meeting.
Mr. James M. Beck was the principal speaker of the evening. In
the course of his speech, he read
an extract from an article which he
said was written by a professor at
Johns Hoplcins.
He attacked American colleges,
calling them "mere social clubs."
He said that in the teaching of
American history the points that
we could not feel proud of were
omitted, while the bright points
were dwelt upon. A college degree
should not be granted, he declared,
unless the student had the knowledge of both the good and the bad
parts of American history. He said
he would like to try an experiment
on a hundred students composed of
the ten brightest students from each
of the ten leading colleges. He
said he was willing to wager that
of this number not more than one
could correctly answer when America first received help from France.
He favored a standing army of
550,000 men, which number, although only about one-quarter of
the size of the standing armies of
Germany and France, he thought
sufficient to protect our shores. As
to our coast defenses, he pointed out
that they were strong enough to
resist a direct attack from the front,
but that as the guns could not be
reversed they would easily fall if
attacked from the rear by a land
force.
He favored international arbitration, not because he believed it
would do away with war, but because it would minimize the chance
for war.
Mr.William Marbury spoke next.
Following his address, a telegram
from Theodore Roosevelt, complimenting the patriotic spirit of
Maryland, was read by Governor
Goldsborough.

(Continued on page 8, col. 2)

The alumni of the University of
New York have resumed their campaign to raise a million dollars for
the financial support of the university. Dr. S. E. Mezes, formerly
president of the University. of
Texas, is the head of the University of New York, which is now
rated as being the eighth largest
university in America.—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 6, 1915.

DR. REID ON CANAL COMMITTEE

BOBBY HAS PLAYED LAST GAME HOPKINS MEN SAIL WITH FORD

Hopkins Geologist Appointed to Assist
in Investigation of Slides at Panama.
Will Visit Zone this Month.

Hoffman, Bright Backfield Star of Hopkins Team, to Stop Football.
Parental Objections.

Prof. Harry Fielding Reid, of
Johns Hopkins University, has been
appointed a member of the committee of the National Academy of
Sciences to report on the condition
arising out of the recent slide of
earth into the Panama Canal.
These slides of rock and earth
present one of the most serious difficulties which the engineers digging the canal have encountered,
and have led President Wilson to
ask the National Academy of Sciences to appoint a committee to
consider and report on the possibility of controlling them.
This committee has been appointed, and, besides Professor Reid,
consists of the following: Prof. C.
R. Van Hise, University of Wisconsin, chairman; Gen. H. L. Abbott, Cambridge, Mass.; Dr. George
F. Becker, United States Geological Survey; Prof. J. C. Brunner,
Leland Stanford University; Dr.
Whitman Cross, United States Geological Survey; Dr. Arthur L.Day,
Carnegie Institution; Dr.J. L.Hayward, Northwestern University;
Prof. R. S. Woodward, Carnegie
Institution; Mr. R. C. Carpenter,
engineer, Ithaca, N. Y.; Mr. Arthur P. Davis, United States Reclamation Service; and Mr. John
R. Freeman, engineer, Providence,
R. I.
The committee expects to visit
Panama this month, and to make
a report to the President on its
return.

Bobby Hoffman, the star for the
last two years of the Hopkins football team, has played his last game
of football. The freshman-sophomore contest on Saturday marked
the close of a football career that,
starting at City College three years
ago, gradually ascended until this
season it lifted Hoffman head and
shoulders above every other halfback in the State, and even placed
him in the same ranks as the best
men of the larger college teams.
This came rather as a surprise.
Except for having his wind knocked
out for a few minutes in the recent St. John's game, Hoffman
has never been hurt or knocked
unconscious during his whole football career. He has always trained
faithfully and this, combined, with
a solid, sturdy build, has kept him
safe from all ordinary injuries. He
knows how to fall when tackled,
and can be hurled hard against the
ground and become the bottom of
a struggling, fighting mass without
being hurt in the least.
But in spite of this, Hoffman
has decided not to play again. Although his parents have not absolutely forbidden him to play, still
Hoffman, knowing that they strongly object, has determined to do as
they wish him to and give up the
game.
With Hoffman out of the game,
next year's team will have difficulty
in finding a back who can run and
kick as Hoffman can. Bobby has
equaled the best in this country in
drop-kicking. It is safe to say that
few, if any, other college men in
the United States can surpass this
Hopkins player in the precision,
speed and distance of his kicks.
Besides drop-kicking, Hoffman has
done all the punting for Hopkins
this year, and in almost every game
far outdistanced his opponents. As
a broken-field runner and as a line
plunger Bobby held his own with
any man in the State.
Hopkins' football .will suffer, but
then the Black and Blue will still
have Hoffman on the lacrosse team.
Here he is also a shining light, being one of the steadiest defense
men Hopkins has had for years,
and this somewhat helps us to forget his loss to the football team.

Pittsburgh or Cornell, Which?

Who won the Eastern inter-collegiate football championship, PittsPittsburgh
burgh or Cornell?
thinks it has a right to the title
and has issued a challenge to Cornell asking that a game be played
between the two colleges sometime
within the next two weeks. It is
not likely that Cornell will play
Pitt, as her players have already
broken training and it would take
time to get them again into prime
condition.
Harvard is also ready to dispute
for the championship, claiming that
her team was not playing in its
usual form when it met Cornell.
Syracuse also had a team of
championship ability, and would
have been a strong contender for
the title if she had not been nosed
out by Princeton by a close score.

Bruce Williams and Edgar Fell,of Political Economy Department, Leave
with Peace Delegation of
Automobile King.

Bruce Williams and Edgar Fell.
graduate students in the political
science department of this University, sailed Saturday with Mr.
Henry Ford on the Oscar II for
Europe. Mr. Fell is the son of Dr.
Thomas Fell, president of St. John's
College and provost of the University of Maryland.
Three Hopkins men—Williams,
Fell and Dorsey Richardson—applied to Mr. Ford for passage on
the peace ship when they heard that
a representative of Johns Hopkins
was to be taken. Mr. Ford's secretary wired back that one of the trio
could be taken, but later stated that
no representative of Johns Hopkins
could go. At the last moment, however, Messrs. Fell and Williams
were told to get passports and to
go at once to New York. There
they were told that they were to be
taken on the peace-seeking expedition.
The Oscar II sailed on Saturday
amid highly-exciting circumstances.
Mr. Ford was besieged by eleventhhour cal:ers, and the crowd at the
dock was tremendous. The Hopkins delegates arrived in time to
board the ship.

FREDDIE LEE COACHES WINNING
TRACK TEAM AT WISCONSIN

Frederic C. Lee, A. B. '12, who
IS working for a doctor's degree
in .chemistry at the University of
Wisconsin, coached the crossCountry team of that institution to
the conference championship this
fall. The score of the Wisconsin
team in the inter-conference chamPionship meet, which was held on
November 20, was thirty - eight
Points, the low score for the championship run of five miles. Mr.
Lee's team also defeated Minnesota
in their dual meet by the score of
24 to 33.
Mr. Lee says, in his letter to a
student of our University:
"I would like to say that I am not
teaching at the university (Wisconsin), as a great many people seem
to think, but am with the United
States government as research assistant in forest products.
"I was immensely proud of our
(J. H. U.) football team this fall,
and was only sorry that I could not
be on hand to root for them and see
them in action. I take this opportunity to send them my heartiest
Congratulations."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 6, 1915.

BIG BASKET-BALL GAME PLANNED

REMOVAL TO BEGIN JUNE 1

Hopkins Independents and Homewood
Hopefuls to Clash on Floor--Managers
Brinton and Bagley Optimistic.

First Section of Library to Go to Homewood on that Date—Efficient Scheme
of Handling Books Devised.

The sporting element at the University will be delighted to hear
that a contest has at last been arranged between the Hopkins independent basket-ball team, captained
by Myron E. Bagley, and the
Homewood Hopefuls, a fast-traveling quintet that is winning for itself an enviable reputation this season under the able leadership of
Head Coach Jeffries Buck Brinton.
The independent team has enenjoyed unquestioned sway in former years, and the challenge from
Brinton's pets was consequently received with no mean degree of concern. Captain Bagley immediately
set about putting his men through a
most rigorous drill, however, and
they should now prove able to give
the challengers a terrible fight for
honors. Captain Bagley's plan is
to teach his team the fundamentals
of the game. "Once on their feet,"
he smilingly explained to a NEwsLETTER correspondent, "I shall
trust my boys to the limit. I am
by no means inclined to underestitame the strength of Brinton's combination, but I have taught my
men to play hard, clean basket-ball,
varied with an occasional reversion
to the open Western game, and I
'fail to see how they could go down
under anything less than an avalanche."
Coach Brinton, it must be admitted, is equally optimistic as to the
outcome of the contest. He feels
that he has uncovered a veritable
little wizard in Leibensperger, while
Brickley, too, has proved a consistent ground-gainer throughout
the season. "My gladiators have
been going well all season," he remarked. 'They will eat Bagley's
team up."
No date for the contest has as
yet been set, as Brickley's eligibility
has not been fully conceded by the
independents. The game will probably take place next week, however, and, with favorable climatic
conditions, a record-breaking crowd
is expected to be present.
The rival line-ups follow:
Homewoods—Wilkinson, center;
Leibensperger, right forward;
Brickley, left forward; Brinton,
right guard; Schmidt, left guard.
Independents — Bagley, center;
Branham, right forward; Pfitsch,
left forward; Brooks, right guard;
Martindale, left guard.
Timekeepers—C. Staley and J.
Johnson.
Referee—W. Fernandis.

Preparations for the removal of
the University to the new quarters
at Homewood consist now mainly
of calculations of the cost of moving the library and laboratories and
ot devising efficient schemes for the
most speedy transportation possible.
Plans have already been formulated for the removal of the library.
This work will be started about the
first of June and will be completed
in about three weeks. The plan
proposed for the removal of the
books is that boxes just as long as
the shelves of the library be constructed and that entire shelves of
books conveyed to Homewood intact. This will avoid confusion of
the books and will facilitate the task
of replacing them on the shelves of
the new library.
At the time set for the removal
the examinations will be about over
and most of the books will be available. Owing to the fact that the
summer session will be held in
McCoy Hall this year, some of the
books will have to be left; these will
be shelved in the main reading-room
while needed by the summer students.
Present circumstances forecast
the successful carrying out of all
plans. The next academic year will
be opened at Homewood.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—I wish to express the appreciation of myself and a few friends
of the football reviews which Mr.
Brickley has been writing for THE
•NEws - LETTER. These accounts
came each week as a matter of
great interest to every reader with
whom I have spoken on the subject, and I do not think I am far
wrong when I say that every student holds the same opinion as
mine.
• If Mr. Brickley will only return
to coach Hopkins again next year
I feel sure that more things than
we think of now will be done by our
team. His appearance in Baltimore
has certainly made a bigger hit than
that of any other athletic coach I
ever heard of.
ADMIRER.

DR. WOOD MAKES DISCOVERIES

HOPKINS MEN AT MEETING

Dr. Singewald, on Return from South
America, Reports Gathering of Valuable Mineral Specimens—Ore
Deposits Studied.

Underclass Teams Fight at Homewood
to Standstill - -Sophs Have Advantage, but Fail to Score at
Critical Times.

Planets Found by Him to Show Different
New Features When Photographed
by Varied Processes at Mount
Wilson, California.

Many University Representatives Present
at National Defense Gathering at

Sends Congratulations.

Dr. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr.,
associate in economic geology at
Johns Hopkins University, has just
returned from a seven months' tour
of South and Central America,
bringing with him the most valuable collection of South American
ores that has ever been brought
together at one time. He was accompanied on the trip by Prof.
Benjamin L. Miller, of Lehigh
University, a graduate in geology
of this University.
The purpose of the trip was to
make a study of the ore deposits
of Latin America. In the course
of the trip, Professor Singewald
visited practically all of the most
important mines of the countries
through which he passed.
In addition to the value of this
material for museum and lecture
Purposes, much of it is of scientific
importance, It includes fossils
from two series of rocks in Bolivia
in which fossils had never before
been found, whose study is expected to throw great light upon the
geological history of the Andes.
Data was also collected from the
nitrate fields of Chile which will
Probably help to settle the vexatious problem of their origin. Results bearing on the problems of
ore genesis are expected from the
laboratory investigations of the ore
specimens.
South America has the most
varied mineral deposits of all the
continents, and many mineralogical
specimens of particular value were
obtained. Among the most striking additions to the mineral collections of the University are large
specimens of native bismuth from
Huayna Potosi, near La Paz, Bolivia, a mineral that is only found
in small quantities elsewhere; a
magnificent specimen of silver ore
from near Cerro de Pasco, Peru;
arborescent bunches of native copner from Coroco, Bolivia; and
great quantities of the otherwise
rare oxidized basic copper ores that
occur so abundantly in the Atacama
desert in Chile.
Dr. Singewald was much impressed with the •important position
that South America deserves and is
rapidly establishing for herself as a
contributor to the world's supply
of metals. Her progress in this
spect is shown by the number of
Points in which she holds first place.
Dr. Singewald also came into contact in every region which he visited with the activities of foreign
nations in the development of the
country.

The annual freshman-sophomore
football game, played Saturday at
Homewood, ended in a scoreless tie.
It was a hard-fought battle throughout, with the sophomores perhaps
having a little the better of the argument. The play was in freshman
territory practically the whole game,
the second-year men twice getting
within striking distance of the freshmen's goal. But the sophomores
lacked the punch at the critical moments, and the first-year men were
able to keep their goal line untouched.
Hoffman had two chances to
drop-kick, but both attempts went
far from their mark. At the end
of the first half the sophomores
were close to the goal line, but instead of attempting a drop-kick the
second-year men tried for a touchdown and were held for downs by
the freshies on their i-yard line.
The contest started off with a
rush. Hoffman kicked off. The
sophs were very fast getting down
the field and a general scramble for
the ball ensued. A first-year man
finally fell on it. They failed to
gain, and on the fourth down Frock
kick ed to Hoffman. Duncan
plunged through center and made it
first down. In three successive
rushes Hoffman netted twenty-two
yards, but after each gain his team
was penalized, and he was forced
to kick.
Here ensued a kicking duel between Frock and Hoffman, the
quarter ending with the ball in the
freshmen's possession.
At the beginning of the second
quarter, the freshmen were forced
to kick. Cort missed the ball and
a freshman fell on it. The freshmen then tried a trick play, which
only netted them five yards. The
ball went over on downs.
Hoffman and Duncan now alternated in carrying the ball, and were
able to advance within a yard of
the goal line, but here the freshies
took a brace and held them on the
fourth down. Frock kicked out of
danger. The sophs tried a forward
pass, but missed out by a small
margin.
The half ended with the ball almost in the center of the field.
The third quarter consisted mainly of a kicking duel between Hoffman and Frock, with the advantage
slightly in the soph's favor.
The fourth quarter almost saw
a sophomore victory. Repeated
gains by Duncan and Hoffman
brought the ball under the freshies'

Dr. Robert Wood, Johns Hopkins' celebrated professor of experimental physics, has just retttrned to the University after
making a successful series of experiments at the Mt. Wilson Observatory, situated at Pasadena,
Cal. Dr. Wood's visit to California
was primarily for the purpose of
photographing the moon through
the powerful 60-inch telescope on
Mt. Wilson. However, so much
more material for study was found
among the planets that Dr. Wood
changed his intentions and spent
most of his time photographing
them instead of the 1110011.
In his work, Dr. Wood photographed the moon, Mars, Jupiter
and Saturn with the aid of yellow
light and the ultra-violet and infrared rays. It was found that substances that could be photographed
by means of ultra-violet rays were
at times not shown on the plates
taken with the infra-red rays. For
example, on the ultra-violet photographs Saturn showed a broad,
dark belt around the equator that
could not be seen on the proofs of
the infra-red photographs. Differences in the polar caps and the
rings of Saturn were also noticed.
Dr. Wood explained these phenomena by saying that the atmosphere of the planet possibly contained finely-divided dust or some
gas that was opaque to one kind of
ray and transparent to another.
Jupiter, as well as Saturn,
showed such differences. In order
to discover the nature, of the materials that photograph so differently
under the various rays, it will be
necessary, Dr. Wood says, to make
further investigations. This is now
being done at the California observatory.
In photographing with the infrared and the ultra-violet rays,
screens have to be arranged that
exclude all except the particular
kind of ray to, be used. In the
use of the ultra-violet rays the
light is filtered by means of a glass
cell, closed by quartz and containing bromine vapor.
Dr. Wood is particularly pleased
with the results of these experiments. It is unknown yet just
what importance these facts will
have on our ideas of the planets;
but, at any rate, Dr. Wood's observations are the first of their kind,
and to Dr. Wood belongs the credit
of the discoveries.

Hopkins men were very much in
evidence at the mass-meeting for
national defense, held at the Lyric
Saturday night. The ushers and
many of the vice-presidents were
representatives of the University,
and there were many Hopkins men
in the audience. Governor Goldsborough presided over the meeting.
Mr. James M. Beck was the principal speaker of the evening. In
the course of his speech, he read
an extract from an article which he
said was written by a professor at
Johns Hoplcins.
He attacked American colleges,
calling them "mere social clubs."
He said that in the teaching of
American history the points that
we could not feel proud of were
omitted, while the bright points
were dwelt upon. A college degree
should not be granted, he declared,
unless the student had the knowledge of both the good and the bad
parts of American history. He said
he would like to try an experiment
on a hundred students composed of
the ten brightest students from each
of the ten leading colleges. He
said he was willing to wager that
of this number not more than one
could correctly answer when America first received help from France.
He favored a standing army of
550,000 men, which number, although only about one-quarter of
the size of the standing armies of
Germany and France, he thought
sufficient to protect our shores. As
to our coast defenses, he pointed out
that they were strong enough to
resist a direct attack from the front,
but that as the guns could not be
reversed they would easily fall if
attacked from the rear by a land
force.
He favored international arbitration, not because he believed it
would do away with war, but because it would minimize the chance
for war.
Mr.William Marbury spoke next.
Following his address, a telegram
from Theodore Roosevelt, complimenting the patriotic spirit of
Maryland, was read by Governor
Goldsborough.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 6, 1915.

DR. REID ON CANAL COMMITTEE

BOBBY HAS PLAYED LAST GAME HOPKINS MEN SAIL WITH FORD

Hopkins Geologist Appointed to Assist
in Investigation of Slides at Panama.
Will Visit Zone this Month.

Hoffman, Bright Backfield Star of Hopkins Team, to Stop Football.
Parental Objections.

Prof. Harry Fielding Reid, of
Johns Hopkins University, has been
appointed a member of the committee of the National Academy of
Sciences to report on the condition
arising out of the recent slide of
earth into the Panama Canal.
These slides of rock and earth
present one of the most serious difficulties which the engineers digging the canal have encountered,
and have led President Wilson to
ask the National Academy of Sciences to appoint a committee to
consider and report on the possibility of controlling them.
This committee has been appointed, and, besides Professor Reid,
consists of the following: Prof. C.
R. Van Hise, University of Wisconsin, chairman; Gen. H. L. Abbott, Cambridge, Mass.; Dr. George
F. Becker, United States Geological Survey; Prof. J. C. Brunner,
Leland Stanford University; Dr.
Whitman Cross, United States Geological Survey; Dr. Arthur L.Day,
Carnegie Institution; Dr.J. L.Hayward, Northwestern University;
Prof. R. S. Woodward, Carnegie
Institution; Mr. R. C. Carpenter,
engineer, Ithaca, N. Y.; Mr. Arthur P. Davis, United States Reclamation Service; and Mr. John
R. Freeman, engineer, Providence,
R. I.
The committee expects to visit
Panama this month, and to make
a report to the President on its
return.

Bobby Hoffman, the star for the
last two years of the Hopkins football team, has played his last game
of football. The freshman-sophomore contest on Saturday marked
the close of a football career that,
starting at City College three years
ago, gradually ascended until this
season it lifted Hoffman head and
shoulders above every other halfback in the State, and even placed
him in the same ranks as the best
men of the larger college teams.
This came rather as a surprise.
Except for having his wind knocked
out for a few minutes in the recent St. John's game, Hoffman
has never been hurt or knocked
unconscious during his whole football career. He has always trained
faithfully and this, combined, with
a solid, sturdy build, has kept him
safe from all ordinary injuries. He
knows how to fall when tackled,
and can be hurled hard against the
ground and become the bottom of
a struggling, fighting mass without
being hurt in the least.
But in spite of this, Hoffman
has decided not to play again. Although his parents have not absolutely forbidden him to play, still
Hoffman, knowing that they strongly object, has determined to do as
they wish him to and give up the
game.
With Hoffman out of the game,
next year's team will have difficulty
in finding a back who can run and
kick as Hoffman can. Bobby has
equaled the best in this country in
drop-kicking. It is safe to say that
few, if any, other college men in
the United States can surpass this
Hopkins player in the precision,
speed and distance of his kicks.
Besides drop-kicking, Hoffman has
done all the punting for Hopkins
this year, and in almost every game
far outdistanced his opponents. As
a broken-field runner and as a line
plunger Bobby held his own with
any man in the State.
Hopkins' football .will suffer, but
then the Black and Blue will still
have Hoffman on the lacrosse team.
Here he is also a shining light, being one of the steadiest defense
men Hopkins has had for years,
and this somewhat helps us to forget his loss to the football team.

Pittsburgh or Cornell, Which?

Who won the Eastern inter-collegiate football championship, PittsPittsburgh
burgh or Cornell?
thinks it has a right to the title
and has issued a challenge to Cornell asking that a game be played
between the two colleges sometime
within the next two weeks. It is
not likely that Cornell will play
Pitt, as her players have already
broken training and it would take
time to get them again into prime
condition.
Harvard is also ready to dispute
for the championship, claiming that
her team was not playing in its
usual form when it met Cornell.
Syracuse also had a team of
championship ability, and would
have been a strong contender for
the title if she had not been nosed
out by Princeton by a close score.

Bruce Williams and Edgar Fell,of Political Economy Department, Leave
with Peace Delegation of
Automobile King.

Bruce Williams and Edgar Fell.
graduate students in the political
science department of this University, sailed Saturday with Mr.
Henry Ford on the Oscar II for
Europe. Mr. Fell is the son of Dr.
Thomas Fell, president of St. John's
College and provost of the University of Maryland.
Three Hopkins men—Williams,
Fell and Dorsey Richardson—applied to Mr. Ford for passage on
the peace ship when they heard that
a representative of Johns Hopkins
was to be taken. Mr. Ford's secretary wired back that one of the trio
could be taken, but later stated that
no representative of Johns Hopkins
could go. At the last moment, however, Messrs. Fell and Williams
were told to get passports and to
go at once to New York. There
they were told that they were to be
taken on the peace-seeking expedition.
The Oscar II sailed on Saturday
amid highly-exciting circumstances.
Mr. Ford was besieged by eleventhhour cal:ers, and the crowd at the
dock was tremendous. The Hopkins delegates arrived in time to
board the ship.

FREDDIE LEE COACHES WINNING
TRACK TEAM AT WISCONSIN

Frederic C. Lee, A. B. '12, who
IS working for a doctor's degree
in .chemistry at the University of
Wisconsin, coached the crossCountry team of that institution to
the conference championship this
fall. The score of the Wisconsin
team in the inter-conference chamPionship meet, which was held on
November 20, was thirty - eight
Points, the low score for the championship run of five miles. Mr.
Lee's team also defeated Minnesota
in their dual meet by the score of
24 to 33.
Mr. Lee says, in his letter to a
student of our University:
"I would like to say that I am not
teaching at the university (Wisconsin), as a great many people seem
to think, but am with the United
States government as research assistant in forest products.
"I was immensely proud of our
(J. H. U.) football team this fall,
and was only sorry that I could not
be on hand to root for them and see
them in action. I take this opportunity to send them my heartiest
Congratulations."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 6, 1915.

BIG BASKET-BALL GAME PLANNED

REMOVAL TO BEGIN JUNE 1

Hopkins Independents and Homewood
Hopefuls to Clash on Floor--Managers
Brinton and Bagley Optimistic.

First Section of Library to Go to Homewood on that Date—Efficient Scheme
of Handling Books Devised.

The sporting element at the University will be delighted to hear
that a contest has at last been arranged between the Hopkins independent basket-ball team, captained
by Myron E. Bagley, and the
Homewood Hopefuls, a fast-traveling quintet that is winning for itself an enviable reputation this season under the able leadership of
Head Coach Jeffries Buck Brinton.
The independent team has enenjoyed unquestioned sway in former years, and the challenge from
Brinton's pets was consequently received with no mean degree of concern. Captain Bagley immediately
set about putting his men through a
most rigorous drill, however, and
they should now prove able to give
the challengers a terrible fight for
honors. Captain Bagley's plan is
to teach his team the fundamentals
of the game. "Once on their feet,"
he smilingly explained to a NEwsLETTER correspondent, "I shall
trust my boys to the limit. I am
by no means inclined to underestitame the strength of Brinton's combination, but I have taught my
men to play hard, clean basket-ball,
varied with an occasional reversion
to the open Western game, and I
'fail to see how they could go down
under anything less than an avalanche."
Coach Brinton, it must be admitted, is equally optimistic as to the
outcome of the contest. He feels
that he has uncovered a veritable
little wizard in Leibensperger, while
Brickley, too, has proved a consistent ground-gainer throughout
the season. "My gladiators have
been going well all season," he remarked. 'They will eat Bagley's
team up."
No date for the contest has as
yet been set, as Brickley's eligibility
has not been fully conceded by the
independents. The game will probably take place next week, however, and, with favorable climatic
conditions, a record-breaking crowd
is expected to be present.
The rival line-ups follow:
Homewoods—Wilkinson, center;
Leibensperger, right forward;
Brickley, left forward; Brinton,
right guard; Schmidt, left guard.
Independents — Bagley, center;
Branham, right forward; Pfitsch,
left forward; Brooks, right guard;
Martindale, left guard.
Timekeepers—C. Staley and J.
Johnson.
Referee—W. Fernandis.

Preparations for the removal of
the University to the new quarters
at Homewood consist now mainly
of calculations of the cost of moving the library and laboratories and
ot devising efficient schemes for the
most speedy transportation possible.
Plans have already been formulated for the removal of the library.
This work will be started about the
first of June and will be completed
in about three weeks. The plan
proposed for the removal of the
books is that boxes just as long as
the shelves of the library be constructed and that entire shelves of
books conveyed to Homewood intact. This will avoid confusion of
the books and will facilitate the task
of replacing them on the shelves of
the new library.
At the time set for the removal
the examinations will be about over
and most of the books will be available. Owing to the fact that the
summer session will be held in
McCoy Hall this year, some of the
books will have to be left; these will
be shelved in the main reading-room
while needed by the summer students.
Present circumstances forecast
the successful carrying out of all
plans. The next academic year will
be opened at Homewood.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—I wish to express the appreciation of myself and a few friends
of the football reviews which Mr.
Brickley has been writing for THE
•NEws - LETTER. These accounts
came each week as a matter of
great interest to every reader with
whom I have spoken on the subject, and I do not think I am far
wrong when I say that every student holds the same opinion as
mine.
• If Mr. Brickley will only return
to coach Hopkins again next year
I feel sure that more things than
we think of now will be done by our
team. His appearance in Baltimore
has certainly made a bigger hit than
that of any other athletic coach I
ever heard of.
ADMIRER.
November 30, 1915.

goal posts. Cort took the ball
through center over the line, but the
referee penalized the.sophs for pulling their man. Hoffman next tried

The game ended without any
other chances for a score.
For the sophs, Hoffman and Duncan in the backfield, and Chalmers,
Woodward and Egerton on the line,
played the most consistent game.
Frock, Cox, Myers and Frisch
played the best for the freshies.
During the intermission between
the halves the freshmen and sophomores had a rush in front of the
freshman stand. The fight was
staged because the freshmen had
not upheld the custom and flaunted
a banner.
During the last half, however, the
freshies displayed an old piece of
canvas with a green "19" painted
on it. After the game, the sophomores went after this "banner," and
in a. few minutes there was not
much left of it.
